For necessity and modesty teach us
to cover the Body, and put on clothes,
especially here in the North, under the Great Bear,
which nowadays hands over our heads.

2. The Body, wonderfully created, exceeds
in honor all kinds of precious linen,
thread from silkworms, and clothes of Tyrian purple:
and those who are our antipodes,
living in the tranquil kingdom of Saturn,
unaware of shame, care nothing for clothes.
Yet reason, creating an honorable modesty,
guides us to a suitably moderate clothing.
left-middleThe well-made Human Body, more beautiful than all manner of clothing.
left-middleIn India they go naked, but here shame teaches us to be clothed

3. One dresses for one’s own station,
that is, according to a person’s esteem:
Kings wear purple, ornamented with Crowns,
and cheerful Youths are pleased to deck themselves
in brilliant, exquisite colors,
while maidens will favor white. In these matters,
Painters must pay close attention to all,
To clothe each thus according to one’s station.
left-middleClothing depends on the person. Colors of clothes according to the nature and age of each.

4. Black, today as in earlier times, signifies mourning,
as will be described in due course;
it is thus that Widows and Old Men are dressed.
Likewise, Shepherds and Boatmen should be given
coarsely woven woolen Fabric,
in various shades of gray,
worn tight around the body, with large folds,
and rarely adorned with bright colors.

5. All that Arachne’s Art offers in abundance,
we must observe with diligent attention,
starting with Cloth that weavers roll from the rough warp, and others: wools
velvets, serges, silks, how each creates folds
according to its nature, taking care not to paint
ropes, sails, or intestines, but real Cloth,
appearing flat, hanging or rumpled.
left-middleVarious Cloths; observing different folds or creases.
left-middleBeginning with the Cloth which Weavers roll.

6. Coarse Linen makes straight folds
with sharp corners, like wet Paper.
One sees jagged crumpling of this sort
quite often in Dürer’s fabric;
though painting of the fine rumpled cloth
worn, say, by children of the Madonna,
one can find no better example
than those by Mabuse, if truth be told.
